review_title: Its not bad, its not great
job_title: Event Transportation Specialist in Pullman, WA
pros: - You get the most flexible job you've ever had - You get one of the highest pays for a student job despite being parttime - The staff above you are very accommodating and nice -Super forgiving as its a student employment job -As long as you have some way to entertain yourself for a few hours, you get paid to sit around basically and you can do whatever as long as you're there
cons: When they say flexible, they truly mean that your hours are there when an event is going on. But if you have class or other responsibilities? You can kiss those hours goodbye. The most hours you'll ever get weekly is based on how available you are for events generally, and once its the spring semester, there is no requirement to do almost all the events excluding graduation. If you're using this job as your main source of income, then you may go two weeks without working, and then only get scheduled one shift that may be 4 hours, or may be as much as 13. Which doesn't sound too bad, into you take into account that you're sometimes working in conditions that aren't great. Negative Degree weather, sometimes rain, sunburning conditions, and you don't get a break unless you have to pee. Which again, isn't the worse thing ever, I mean you get paid to sit around and occasionally direct people. Yet, is it truly great when you have such rare hours, and need to make money? What if you have class? Is this really a dependable source of income? I'd recommend that anyone that is looking for a stable source of income, don't look into this position specifically. Its not bad, but its not great either.

review_title: Great culture and benefits, average wages
pros: The people are great to work with. You learn a lot being involved with so many facets of a research university. Work/life balance and benefits are excellent. Colleagues are friendly and helpful.
cons:
The salary for web developers is ~20% below market rate and the HR department has difficulty distinguishing between advanced content editors and web developers. Many are lumped into the same classification of web coordinator, which is a glorified web generalist/content editor.

Some back end developers are lucky enough to be classified as application systems analysts, but if you find yourself in between those two classifications working on mostly front end theming and configuration, you will be stuck in the lower salary classification. If you find yourself in this position, I strongly suggest using your experience to find a job that pays what you're worth.

review_title: Departmental Leadership Will Make or Break You, and Be Ready for Small Town Woes
pros: Good benefits, vacation time, decent starting pay, and reliable pay increases for hourly employees.  Complex structure means there are a lot of ways to get your foot in the door. Good place to change careers.
cons:
The leadership within your department will determine your job satisfaction. If leadership is poor, your only real choice is to get out. Resources for conflict resolution are so ineffective that they may as well be non-existent, and HR is either unable or unwilling to do anything to correct or remove bad managers. (It's easier to just treat problems as isolated incidents caused by personality conflicts, changes in management, etc., rather than seriously address toxic work environments or admit that perhaps someone was hired or promoted  who should not have been.)

Aside from that, WSU is very remote.  It's an ok area if you like small-town living and have family and friends nearby, but you are likely to get bored if you're moving from elsewhere and travel to and from is a hassle. Lastly, be prepared for a tough housing market. Rents are high for such a small place (because of the university) and rental properties are plagued by bad management used to dealing with college students. The real estate market heavily favors sellers. And in both cases, vacancies follow the academic year. Renters and buyers better have a place under contract by April at the latest - apartments get snapped up by incoming students and houses literally sell in a matter of days once summer comes.

review_title: Great place to end or damage your career
pros: A peaceful town with kind and friendly people. Great if you want to focus on studies for a year or two such as MS or a postdoc. Great for football lovers.
cons:
The below recommendations are for graduate students and postdocs.
Be prepared to have zero networking opportunities with industry or business since the school has no money to send you to a conference or host one. Most faculty have an 80s mindset and are depressed because they realize that their career will end at WSU (department of Physics and Chemistry). Low funding and RA salary since school culture are more focused on football than research. Also, all libraries close at 10 pm or before, and there is nowhere to work beside your apartment or a bar. If you are a foreign Ph.D. student you will have a miserable time as you will be trapped there with no opportunities to get out. I saw brilliant graduate students being intellectually suffocated in this place over a year or two. And most of them had issues finding jobs in their field and ended up as a programmer. You'd better have a really good reason and an appropriate personality to go there besides just loving your work. So think twice if you pack your luggage and move to Pullman.

But if you decided to go there, I suggest you do MS level studies in engineering, business, or veterinary. Going for a Ph.D. study at WSU without previous experience in industry likely is not a good idea.

review_title: The university will just as soon fire you a let you move vertically up university
pros: Decent Health Benefits and Retirement is TIAA-CREFF. Great hours as salary when AP staff becuase you can come and go as you want and you get paid equal amounts. Most supervisors allow for this unofficial/unspoken agreement. I worked for the last year at less than 30 a week and got paid for 40 plus full vacation time (This is a Con in one aspect becuase it is a huge waste of tax payer money.
cons: The university doesn't care about you at all. If you and your supervisor agree you should get a raise HR will just turn around and say no. This means it is extremely hard to get a raise if you are not faculty. If you are civil service you will only get your pay increase until you top out (at about 5 years) and then you will never see another raise, ever.

pros: Low stress, easy to take time off, works really well with home life. Never had a time off request denied. Pay increases fairly quickly.
cons: Lower starting and final pay compared to private employers. Pay set to legislative approvals. There is no negotiating of pay. Redundant and inefficient use of resources. Lack of resources. Often projects are held up waiting on parts or other departments to do their work. Don't expect projects to move along quickly. Unions ineffective, they just collect their dues. There is no bargaining, bargaining agreement is word for word the same as the non-union workers employment agreements. I have been employed here for serveral years and have never met any union reperesentatives. I don't have any idea what they do other than take a cut of my money. Other workers share my feelings on the union representation here.

review_title: An interesting experience, but would not want to call this place home
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Pullman, WA
pros:
-Four seasons, changing scenery, hills and farmland surrounding the city. The Snake River is somewhat nearby, and occasionally out of town one can see some wildlife (primarily red-tailed hawks and coyotes).
-Helpful and friendly coworkers and supervisors.
-Moscow, ID is close by for more shopping opportunities.
-Excellent fitness center, very walkable campus.
-Decent public bus system, especially the Express routes which come every 5-7 minutes during main operating hours.
-Main highways are smooth and well-maintained.
-Cheap, high-quality apartments.
-Sunshine and clear days, beautiful sunsets.
cons:
-Geographically isolated, major urban centers are far away (Seattle, Boise at 5-6 hr, Spokane 90 min, Lewiston/Clarkston 45-50 min). 
-Most businesses (especially restaurants) in Pullman close by 9pm.
-Flights are few (3x/daily) and expensive, and security is more onerous than other airports. In the winter flights can be frequently cancelled as the airport does not have its own tower.
-Roads off of the main streets are generally in worse shape, and the city puts down gravel in the winter.
-Can be windy, not much in the way of trees or other windbreaks.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pullman, WA
pros: School of Mechanical and Materials Engineering has a wide variety of Solid Mechanics, Materials, and Bio-materials research opportunities. With lot of  facility and equipment  and service centers, it is not difficult to find resources for various research. The university also has close ties with Pacific Northwest National Laboratories, which provides further opportunities for research. Although the libraries are not the largest, their inter-library loan system is an invaluable asset; you can virtually access any publication through the system.
cons: Pullman Washington is a rather isolated small town which makes few thing a little challenging; e.g. travelling is a head ache, you can only fly to Seattle from Pullman and if there is a little snow coming down you cannot even do that. Flying out of Spokane (75 miles away) is the most practical way, although it brings its own challenges. On a separate account, since no major company has a store in Pullman, you have to rely on postal services for anything from buying lab supplies to getting your equipment fixed.

review_title: Lots of politics and red tape...Experience can be good or bad, and changes frequently
job_title: Systems Administrator II in Pullman, WA
pros: Can be a good work environment, OK pay, flexible, good training opportunities (6 university credits a semester, $20).  Pullman is small, but wonderful community to grow up in.  Generally speaking, the university has high tech tools (although some notable exceptions in places).
cons: Lots of politics and red tape.  I was eventually fired because I outperformed my coworkers who had been there a long time, and they conspired to get rid of me to keep them from looking bad.  Lots of policy and procedures.  Lots of reasons NOT to excel.  Frequent cycles in outlook due to state budget and other external pressures.  Faculty can be a pain to work with, too.

pros: Typically nice people, working at a University is always a bit more laid back aside from heavy overtime working in IT. cons: Always absurdly political and slow acting in the face of any problem that will ever occur. Worst type of place to work if you want to actually see things get done unless you work on a lower department level.

pros: Great coworkers make all the difference but the benefits are fantastic.  8 hours sick leave and 9.33 - 16.67  hours annual leave per month make their leave accruals some of the best in the area without a doubt.  If you land an AP position you are set.
cons: Civil Service positions take the brunt of the work, blame, and abuse but they make the least by far.  Its pretty top down and the open door policy is just lip service.  You have to pay through the nose for parking but your car will get all dinged up in the lots or garages which is frustrating and you'll still have to walk quite a ways to get to your office anyway if you work near the center of campus.  You will most likely be able to make far more working in private industry.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pullman, WA
pros: Friendly graduate students from all over the world. Everyone I have met in the engineering program is helpful and kind. My research adviser and I have a good relationship, and the classes are challenging but not overly difficult. Cost of living in the city is low which can allow you to save money. Many opportunities for collaborative research, and hands-on time with equipment typically used in your field.
cons: If you do not have a positive relationship with your adviser, you will have challenges when completing your graduate program. Location of campus is isolated, which requires 1.5+ hours to get to the nearest major city. Many students are on Teaching Assistantships rather than research Assistantships. review_title: Great benefits, frustrating bureaucracy and politics
job_title: Marketing Writer and Content Coordinator in Pullman, WA
pros: Great benefits (100% retirement match, especially), fun to work on a college campus. For a marketer, there is no shortage of interesting stories to tell. Culture was pretty relaxed for the most part.
cons: Endless bureaucracy and red tape (fairly typical for a state government entity). Slow work pace. A lot of the "that's the way we've always done it" mentality. I was put into the box of "my job" and wasn't allowed to step outside it very often. The university also tends to reward longevity, as opposed to productivity. You'll run into a lot of older employees who don't work particularly hard or are incompetent, but WSU will never fire them. By the time I left, I felt like I could have given 110% or 30% effort, and it wouldn't have made any difference. I would not have been fired or promoted either way. Not a particularly motivating environment.

pros: In the College of Nursing, great experiences with people and actual research. Was able to negotiate a higher salary on advisor's grant. Spokane has a low cost of living, particularly compared to Seattle and Portland.
cons:
Bureaucracy can be frustrating, and benefits are a headache to organize. 

Depending on the campus you are on, WSU does not have many opportunities for obtaining skills outside of what your advisor can offer you directly with their own time or money, and they will not provide you funding to obtain skills elsewhere.

pros:
Get to work with some of the best vets in the industry. See lots of cases that would never see in private practice. Good state benefits.

Work independently and set own schedule. Lots of trust from my manager made me feel empowered.
cons:
Lots and lots of big egos require careful navigation and serious politicking to get anything new to move forward.

Lack of funding to meet daily needs, maintain equipment, and hire necessary staff, but plenty of funding to build new buildings!

Lack of advancement opportunities once you cap out.

pros: One of the more attractive benefits of the Resident Advisor (RA) job is the full compensation for room and board, meaning that room and board are both paid for as a pseudo-scholarship. Hours are flexible and all staff involved including support staff, administrative staff, supervisors and veteran co-workers are all more than willing to lend a hand to new RA's.
cons: Working as a resident advisor is a fairly large time commitment, you will have to juggle school work along with your RA job. Difficult residents that you will have to supervise might make the job more stressful.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Pullman, WA
pros: great school with strong Plant Pathology Department and access to modern techniques for doing research. Strong scientific community and networking possibilities all over the world. Very friendly staff and international community
cons: Geographically isolated location, there is nothing around except wheat fields that makes it harder to take a break from studying and go to weekend trip. Football season every fall makes it harder to use the campus and move around due to occupation of all parking lots by football fans

review_title: Washington State University enables its developers to research as needed to produce innovative and quality work.
job_title: ITS III (Software Developer III) in Pullman, WA
pros: Excellent work environment and software/hardware tools are a given, when working here.  Fellow developers are easy to work with, and collaboration of ideas flows freely.  This is a good environment for developing personal software skills as well as producing high-class software.
cons: Being in Pullman, it is somewhat removed from large metro areas, but for some, this may be considered a benefit!

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Pullman, WA
pros: The facilities we have access to in the Dept of Horticulture at WSU are extensive and diverse including research orchards across the state, spacious and well-equipped fruit and vegetable storage facilities and sophisticated genomics laboratories.
cons: Pullman is a wonderful place to live; there is nothing like living in a true college town.  Seclusion can be an issue and many find living so far from major cities to be an issue.

pros:
Large university.  Fun, academic atmosphere.  Can take classes for low cost.  
Steady job.  Casual dismissal not likely. Attracts people focused on service to students and research.  Relaxed work atmosphere.  Can find fun, smart people for social life.
cons: Red tape.  Frequent management turnover. Yes-speak culture. Attracts people focused on security and convention. Institutional boards do not support staff concerns.  Staffers grandfathered in even if not functional.  Latent sense among stakeholders of belonging to second-tier state university.  At mercy of state funding.

pros: The people are great, most facilities are new or remodeled. The location of the university allows for most to be far enough away from home that you feel out of state but still paying the in-state tuition
cons: Not a lot to do outside of school and easy to get distracted with social activities if self discipline is an individual struggle

review_title: The employer always worked around class schedules. It made working while in school very easy.
pros: The flexibility was great! Everyone but the managers were students, so there was a lot of common ground between employees. The jobs were fairly simple and would never put any extra stress on the students working there.
cons: The Dining Services job was often mundane and repetitive. Management often failed to deal with issues with some employees who wouldn't ever do all of the work that they should have done.

review_title: Graduate student salary (stipend) in School of Molecular Biosciences
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pullman, WA
pros: Great training. Many opportunities for RA and TAs. Living expenses in Pullman, WA is very cheap that we can actually save money with graduate student's stipend.
cons: It's a small town. The closest major city is Spokane, about an hour drive. Depending on who is going to be your mentor, whether he or she has funding, you may need to do TA for the entire time in graduate school, which will take up a lot of time and definitely slows you down for graduation. However, if you want to get teaching job in the future, this could be a real plus.

job_title: General Manager in Swartz Creek, MI
pros: The benefits, pay, vacation package , the way management takes care of your concerns, sick pay, workmanship compensation, lots of hours but the work is really easy! I loved working at General Motors!
cons: It was hot and too much gossip , there was certain people that didn't want the fans on, today I wouldn't be able to do it because I have a bad back and an autistic son..

review_title: Great Intro to IT and help desk management for students
job_title: CougTech Student Coordinator in Pullman, WA
pros: Lots of freedom and collaboration with the other two coordinators to manage a great team of technicians. Great opportunities to learn tech skills and leadership. Paid better than most other campus jobs and allowed for work study.
cons: Lots of changes from main IT that trickled down to the help desk. We were responsible for taking care of them and training the technicians on stuff we didn't know too much about yet.

pros: Flexible, great environment, understanding, and fun! I really enjoyed my time working with the international students on campus and it was great experience while I worked on my degree at the same time.
cons: Only bad experience I had was my manager who had very little to do with anything that I did allowed a difference in opinion to change the way she treated me. That wasn't the universities fault though.

pros: I was given freedom to research what I was interested in, along with the resources to accomplish my research goals. My group had plenty of funding which allowed us to travel to various conferences and have access to training in a variety of situations. The support staff, HR, and other faculty are fantastic.
cons: While I enjoyed the flexibility, perhaps more guidance would have been better to help me mature as a researcher. My group had several projects going which meant that my supervisors were often too engrossed in their own research to pay attention to mine.

job_title: Fiscal Technician II in Pullman, WA
pros:
government position

easy money

growth depending on department
cons:
growth depending on department (DO NOT WORK IN FRENCH AD!!)

politicized

does not stand by their policies regarding employee issues but stands firm when the issue is about money

Delayed/old payroll system (person can either be over or under paid due to department/payroll errors.)

sexism and racism runs rampant (depending on department)

stands firm with illegals as well.

pros: Many people truly want to provide a quality education for the students at Washington State. Pretty good benefits for employees. Nice campus, great community, great school system and low crime.
cons: Working for th State of Washington is a little scary right now with salary freezes, continual budget cuts, etc. Not much real training for most jobs, there are some people who only want to promote themselves and really don't care about the students.

pros: Got to make my own schedule, all my co-workers were nice and seriously cared about the work which we did.  I would definitely take this job back if I was still a student at the school.
cons: The work can be a bit boring at times, but overall you know what you are getting into and the flexibility of the schedule more than makes up for slow days at work.

pros: Business-minded university, fiscally responsible, excellent benefits, great location in pullman, customer-centric culture, positive mission and rewarding work. There are really wonderful people and a surprising number of approachable and down-to-earth faculty. Fascinating and impactful research abounds.
cons: There is some dangerous senior leadership in this college, proceed with caution. Brace yourself for manipulation, cliques, and BIG egos. If you can navigate the politics and kiss hiney at every opportunity, you'll be okay. They don't care about people and you aren't a citizen of this college. People may work here, but the culture does not create deep, lasting, employee investment. Culture and experiences can vary wildly from unit to unit. Elson is a responsible and hardworking president.

pros: Working for a variety of establishments on campus was extremely convenient. I was able to work around my class schedule and had off on holiday breaks etc. I worked o the Pullman campus, I loved the sense of community the campus has to offer.
cons: I think students could be provided with more benefits when working on campus. It can be difficult to manage a full-time student and part-time job. I think more support could be offered to students.

pros: The people that work here both full time and students are typically the best of any department at WSU. As a student they also pay more and actually care about you, plus very willing to work around your schedule.
cons: If you work as a student your shifts will be extremely irregular but there is always classes to be run if you are looking for more hours. When problems arise the workplace can become extremely stressful.

pros:
WSU has invested significantly in upgrading much of its infrastructure, including lab equipment, new buildings and campus-wide broadband. While not an ivy league university, it does rank moderately well in annual surveys. The Agriculture, Veterinary Sciences and Communication colleges are well-ranked. 

WSU recently hired a new president Dr. Elson Floyd. He has his supporters due to his willingness to "shake things up" and elevate the university to a more credible status. For example, in the past year, many "career administrators" have left willingly or been asked to leave. 

The university has a strong sports program and the student enthusiasm for all-things-Cougars is infectious.

Finally, the campus is located in a peaceful, crime-free town Pullman. It is a bit sleepy, but it is a good place to raise a family.
cons:
Money can be tight in some critical areas. For example, most faculty have limited travel budget. Also, the benefits are not amongst the most competitive. Research-track faculty will find rewards for their efforts, but non-tenure and clinical-track faculty will find that they are treated differently - despite promises to the contrary. This lack of parity is obvious when you look at the extra perks offered only to tenured faculty.

Winters are long and unpleasant. 

To some degree, the campus has a bit of a Napolean complex in some areas. Many departments are notorious for having tenured faculty that are not productive in their research. 

Finally, the absolute worst aspect of the campus is the undergraduate student demographic. Mostly white and lacking in critical thinking skills. Also, many have an attitude that they are "customers" that deserve an "A" without making the effort. Beware the "helicopter parents."  Of course, this is a problem at many universities - not just WSU.

review_title: Great learning environment to work in for current students and just-graduated students
job_title: Small-group Facilitator/Writing Consultant in Pullman, WA
pros:
Great programs in place in my department, i.e. the writing program, writing center, small-class teaching/facilitation.  Top notch management in place within the writing center and the small-group writing facilitation program.  Excellent resources available to use with classes and students.  Management accessible and open to discussing any problems or successes you may be having.  Willing to expand your hours somewhat if you prove yourself to be competent and reliable -- and have the time to spare, which I did as a graduate student and then recent graduate for one year.  Provided brief evening trainings once per semester, at the beginning, to refresh our knowledge base and orient new employees.   

Great place to live and work.  Even if you're not from a small town, you'll come to love the secluded atmosphere and quieter life.  Nature is easily accessible here, and Seattle or Portland are just a half day's drive away.
cons:
Not enough hours.  But it's a state university trying to keep everyone below the part-time barrier, so as to avoid large cost increases.  Also, there are always a lot of students who want to work there and are qualified.  Since it is a university, after all, one of its prime objectives is training the employees in job skills they'll use in the real world.  Also, a lot of students are very busy, so divvying up the hours among 40 workers is easier for just about everyone.

Compensation is too low -- but about average based on other writing centers I've worked at.  This isn't a place to make a career because there are hardly any positions to move into (just one or two, one of which requires at least a masters).  It's a springboard to something better, perhaps full-time in a different department in the university, and it's a great experience if you someday want to apply around the country to run a writing center of your own.

I rated it an overall three because it's great if you're a student looking for experience in a supportive environment, but if you want to earn a full-time living you'll have to eventually move on.  However, that doesn't mean you couldn't find something within the university system itself or a different university somewhere else.

pros: It is a aid back environment, friendly coworkers, and the work done at the University is to facilitate all the unique projects, events, research going on. It is a learning environment, where everyone cares for each other.
cons: There is a cap to individual growth in many departments, and there tends to be a lot of turnover. Some of the systems and databases are very old and need to be updated.

pros: Washington State University was a great location to begin a career in science.  In a lab where I had the overview, initially, to keep me learning.  And the independence, to challenge myself and produce top notch research.
cons: Like most university jobs, the salary is on the low side and job security is dependent upon not only how well you work but upon the continued funding of the lab you work.

pros: I had a lot of academic freedom while teaching technical and professional writing, and was able to choose my textbooks and develop course content on my own.

With others, I felt like I came and went for years without anyone knowing or caring about my individual contributions.

I have serious reservations about the ROI on WSU degrees, and that's a shame, because a lot of WSU students don't have many options.

pros: Great traditional benefits (health care, retirement), plus the benefits of working at a university (educational opportunities, cultural events, sports, and more). Pullman's a great town for families, with excellent public schools.
